captions.text:
Step aside, oil pulling - there’s a new
trend in town, and it’s… buttered coffee?
Sounds... rich.

Hey guys, Tara here for Dnews - and every
week, it seems there’s a hot new trend we

should all be getting on board with. Earlier
this month, I came across an interesting article
on something called buttered coffee.

It’s exactly what it sounds like, and while
the idea of adding butter to your coffee might

sound a little too Paula Deen for some, a
lot of people out there swear by it. Even

doctors are touting its benefits, so what’s
the deal? What is buttered coffee, and why
is it good for you?

Well, here’s the official recipe. You take
1 cup of black coffee, add 1-2 tbsp of unsalted

grass-fed butter, and 1-2 tbsp of MCT oil.
Blend until frothy.

MCT stands for medium-chain triglycerides,
and it’s basically a processed mixture of

fats that naturally occur in coconut and palm
kernel oils. MCT oil is more rapidly digested

and metabolized than other types of fats,
so a lot of studies have touted it as a weight

loss supplement - it increases your body’s
ability to burn energy, while decreasing its
fat storage.

It’s a key component of buttered coffee,
but the people who swear by it, also say that

the kind of butter you use, is equally as
important. It MUST be unsalted, and it must

be grass-fed - just organic is not enough.
Same goes for the coffee - ideally, it should

be organic, single-origin beans. Obviously,
this can get pretty expensive - but is it
worth it?

Well, to a lot of people, it is. In addition
to curbing hunger and potentially aiding in

weight loss, people also say it helps with
energy and focus, gives greater mental clarity,

and sustains your coffee buzz for longer - up
to 6 hours - while eliminating the post-caffeine

crash. It also curbs the jittery side effects
and the acid-stomach feeling you get from

drinking straight coffee. And since it’s
technically served frothed, a lot of people

say it just tastes like a fattier latte - which
doesn’t actually sound all that bad.

Now depending on how much butter and MCT oil
you use, a single cup of this stuff contains

anywhere from 200-500 calories, and 45-65
grams of fat - which is 100% of your daily

recommended intake of saturated fat. So how
can something that bad, be good for you? This
is where it gets tricky.

If you were to add buttered coffee to your
daily routine, you would theoretically gain

anywhere from 20-30 lbs per year. So it’s
generally recommended that you use it as a
meal replacement, and not a supplement.

Assuming you agree that good fats are something
your body needs, then that’s fine. But even

people who believe that saturated fats get
“unfairly demonized” say they should be

eaten WITH a meal, not AS the meal. There
are also people out there who say that even

if buttered coffee’s not that bad for you,
a traditional breakfast is still way more

nutritious. And depending on what you’re
eating, that could be entirely true. Consuming

that much butter, can lead to high cholesterol
- and especially so, if you’re not adjusting
other aspects of your diet to accommodate.

Still, I’m a little surprised by how few
doctors seem to warn against it altogether.

Most nutritionists say if you wanna try it
out, go right ahead. But you should probably

get your cholesterol checked first, to make
sure it’s normal.

Personally, I was a little grossed out by
the whole idea of this at first, but I’ll

admit - after reading up on it, it does intrigue
me. So I thought we could do a little experiment.

If this episode gets 5,000 likes - then I
will try buttered coffee for a whole week,

and we’ll upload a follow-up video of my
experience, good or bad. Deal? Deal.

I’m sure some of you out there have tried
it as well, and if you have - we’d love

to know what you think! Just let us know in
the comments, and as always - thank you guys
for watching!

title: Why Are People Drinking Buttered Coffee?

comments.text:
Wow, way too much fuss here about such a simple thing. Just try it. Not 
that big a deal. Butter is just condensed cream. I've drank this combo now 
for almost a year. All good. The combo of butter and MCT oil balances and 
lengthens the effect of the caffeine. 
I'm moderate in my consumption, mainly to minimize overall caffeine 
consumption because its not real convenient. It's more of a treat for me, a 
2-3 times a week. ﻿

comments.author: gary smallwood

comments.text:
What contributes to heart disease isn't just fat in general. It's saturated 
fat that is grain fed. Grass fed saturated fat actually gives the body 
important nutritious elements like Omega-3 Fatty Acids and, like you 
mentioned, Medium Chain Triglycerides (MCT). These fats are important for 
metabolic processes, your body's natural anti-inflammatory and anti-stress 
systems as well as the reduction of bad cholesterol (LDL) by increasing the 
amount of good cholesterol in your body (HDL).

Note: I'm not saying you should go ahead and drink this "buttered coffee" 
anyway, but merely pointing out the fact that there is such a thing as good 
fats out there.You should always consult your doctor or physician before 
you make drastic diet changes.﻿
comments.author: CollegeStudent 94

comments.text:
I don't know about the health benefits but as for taste this doesn't sound 
too good. My suggestion? Well I'm Cuban and a popular practice in our 
culture is to put a pinch of salt in the coffee; NO WAIT, hear me out. It 
may sound weird but anyone with a culinary background will tell you a small 
amount of salt with a relatively large amount of sugar will render a 
slightly buttery rich sweet flavor akin to butterscotch. It's delicious. 
Don't take my word for it Google any recipe for cookies or cake. They all 
have salt as an ingredient for the very same reason. Salt makes sugar taste 
better. Seriously though just a pinch. No one likes salty coffee.﻿

purpose, so I don't recommend the bulletproof set. Grassfed butter + black 
coffee, I recommend if you're coffee addict, better than eating doughnuts + 
black coffee. If you're not a coffee addict, put grassfed butter on bread 
like a normal person. ﻿

comments.text:
NOOOOOOO I'M TIRED OF THIS BULLSHIT!!! Saturated fat and cholesterol are 
GOOD FOR YOU god damn it! The studies that show they are bad for you are 
OUTDATED and HAVE SINCE BEEN PROVEN FALSE! TRANS FATS and POLYUNSATURATED 
FATS are the bad fats! Also, the concept of calories is FALSE! Fat doesn't 
cause blood sugar spikes and therefore insulin resistance and weight gain, 
SUGAR does! Fat is used as a building block - fat helps joints move, helps 
absorb vitamins, helps the brain develop, and only THEN is fat used for 
energy. Protein is used almost exclusively for building the body - very, 
very little is converted into glycogen and used for energy. SUGAR is NOT 
used as a building block - it is only used as fuel. With this being said, 
the idea that all calories can be measured equally regardless from the 
source is absolutely LUDICROUS. So is the idea that somehow arteries work 
like pipes and certain types of fat can just cling onto them. And as far as 
cholesterol... SAME story - it's an essential building block. The body 
actually manufactures most of it's cholesterol. If you eat "too much", 
guess what happens - the body makes less. It's that simple. And if you 
don't eat enough... the body overcompensates and makes way too much. Guys, 
stop believing in bullshit. Seriously. Just because the government tells 
you something is true... doesn't mean it's true. And if any of you are 
going to reply and say "wut lol staurated fats n colesterall is bad fer u 
man, wer did u git ur sorces from?", guess what? I don't give a shit. I'm 
tired of bullshit, and that's all I have to say.﻿
